document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: Tussday was Democratic Day in Appomattox and Buckingham, as a throng of 800 attended the first annual Young Democratic barbecue and rally at beautiful Holiday Lake. A galaxy of political leaders from all sachons of the Old Dominion attended the event, hailed as the largest political rally in this section in the past dacade. After enjoying the musical enter tainment of the crack 45-piece Am erican Legion drum and bugle corps from Lynchburg, the crowd gather ed before a speakers stand nestling in a grove near the 147i-area lake, to hear addresses from many of the distinguished guests. W. M. Ab- bitt, president of the Appomattox Young Democratic Club, presided. Calvin H. Robinson, fourth district chairman, presented visiting Young Democratic leaders. Senator Moses introduced other party leaders pre sent. J. P. Andrews, ip charge of j the federal development in the lake i area, drew applause when he an- ! nounced that a wire received that 1 morning brought news that funds had been made available to finish work on the project. Senator William M. Tuck, of Halifax was presented for a few re marks, following which Harry Griffin of Buckingham introduced Congress man A. Willis Robertson, of Lexing- tqn. Mr. Robertson lauded the Dem ocracy of the Fourth District, and praised the progress in conservation work made by the present national administration. Judge Thomas W. Ozlin was pre sented by Delegate John B. Boat wright. Speaking on the theme of True Liberalism, Mr. Ozlin,. who is a member of the State Corpora tion Commission, launched an at tack on loose financial policies, and urged Virginia Democracy to rally around the leadership of those seek ing to guide from within the party its policies toward liberalism, with out recklessness. Mr. Ozlin declared that many of the current divisions in the Demo- acratic party involved what is and whac fa pot liberalism. He said that true liberals were those who have attempted to uphold the Con stitution of the United States and the financial soundness of the na tion. He attacked any past or fu ture attempts to purge from the party those who were, in reality, its true liberals, in favor of radicals, and political crack-pots.

document.text: Tuesday of this week, Sunset at Appomattox, a documentary film,, produced in Hollywood, had its pre miere before a blue ribbon list of dignataries in Lynchiburg. Nearly 200 saw the advance showing, and came away thrilled at the splendid reproduction of the events of April 9, 1865 at Appomattox. At a dinner at the Virginian Ho tel preceding the showing, Represen tative W. M. Abbitt was toastmaster. Fred Helsaibeck, vice-mayor of the City of Lynchburg, gave the invoca tion. Distinguished guests, including educators and historians, were intro duced. Major-General U. S. Grant, III, grandson of Ulyssis S. Grant, spoke briefly, praising the peace at Appomattox reuniting the na tion. Rev. Richard H. Lee, a kinsman of R. E. Lee, spoke in the same vein. William A. Hart, director of adver tising, E. I. DuPont Company, pro ducers of Sunset at Appomattox, told the story of how the film, was made. Conrad L. Wirth, Director, National Park Service, thanked the DuPont Company for this documen tary contribution. Sunset at Appomattox will be televised nationally on DuPonts Cavalcade of America program, over ABC network, Tuesday night, Oct. 20. We understand WLVA - TV, in Lynchburg carries this program at 730 P. M. Attending the luncheon and the Premiere ... from Appomattox were r Mr. and Mrs. W. M. Abbitt, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. T. document.text: To Tho, Voters of Appomattox County Governor Darden, at the direc tion. of the legislature, has fixed MaNffi. 6, 1945, as the, date to hav a Special election in ..Virginia, up on the question of whether or not the members of our armed force shall be allowed to vpte without pqying a polf .tax or Registering. hp regular Vdifing places will be open as uspal from sunrise to sun set. . As you know there are nearly 109 boys and girls in the armed ,t,rCSpram Appomattox County. Many of them are serving across he ocean thousands of mile- from vie. A number of them will nev- -?.r return. Some are already sleep- ? in lonely graves without a single loved one near to place flowers upon their grave. Others e rsking their lives daily that we might remain at home with our loved ones. Still others have lost their sight, lost arms, legs and other injuries too horrible to men tion. All in the service have gone where they were directed to go and served where told to serve whether on this side of the ocean  or on the other side. They are all doing their duty as commanded. The question is shall we allow these who are fighting and dying for us the privilege to vote or whether we will refuse them this privilege. It is not a question of whether they desire to vote. It is a question of whether they shall have the right to vote if they so desire. We do not believe that any patriotic citizen of Appomattox County, knowing the facts, would intentionally deprive our boys and girls of this great privilege. .veryone who was eligible tt ote last November in the Presi dential election is eligible to vote March 61 In addition all those who have paid 1942, 1943 and 1944 taxes by December 12, 1944 are also eligible to vote taking tax receipts with them to the polls o show election judges. We ear- .estly request every qualified vot er to go to your voting precinct and vote on March 6, 1945, and back our boys and girls. Let them know that we in Appomattox County are behind them in every way............ Signed W. M. Abbitt, George bbitt, Jr., Mrs. S. L. Ferguson, L. F. Ferguson, G. B. Buchanan, R. L. Burke, David T. Robertson. H. W. McKinney, Mrs. Calvin H. Robinson, D. A. Conner Chas. T. Moses.

document.text: The War Fund Campaign of the American Red Cross in Appomattox county to reach a county quota of 1,500 and a goal of 2,000 entered the home stretch this week, with nearly vl,000 already turned in, and -ural stions of the county working o bri g in their reports of funds. As of ast night, the fund treasurer, Calvin H. Robinson, reported that 962.77 had been turned in and in- iic- tions were that when the rural ..ommunities and Junior Rel Cross funds in hand were reported, the otal would approach 1,200. The county quota, assigned by the Am erican National Red Cross in its stupendous effort to raise a special War Fund of no less chan fifty mil lion dollars. County Fund Chairman, the Rev. H. Frederick Jones, has expressed the urgent request that workers and solocitors press their campaign in an effort to reach the quota and the goal by the middle of this month. Chairman Jones has set an example for his co-workers by his nergetic management of the War Fund campaign, and equal work on he part of the other town workers and those sooliciting in the commun ities and rural areas of Appomaitcx will guaranttee success. The American Red Cross needs every penny of the fifty millons re quested of the American people, so lift it can purcahse needed supplies and stand in readiness to uphold its glorious tradition of service to suf fering humanity. Calls upon the Red Cross will inmrease with each pass ing hour in Americas greatest cri sis, and the plea of the organiza-  ion is that the American people, out if the greatness of their 30U i, give the necessary funds. If you have not already given your bit bring or send or mail ycur contribution today to Kev. H. Frederick Jones, Chairman, Appo mattox, Va., or to War Fund Treas urer Calvin H. Simp kins and Mrs. William Thrasher, of Mount Hope, W. Va., Mrs. Thelma Caldwell and Mrs. Charles Hanen- krat, of Appomattox, and Mrs. John Tweedy of this county and one Sis ter, Mrs. S. A. Anderson, of Cram- erton N. C. 15 grandchildren and 1 great grandson. The sympathy of the community is extended to the bereaved family. This expression of Gods will is but another reminder that our sojourn on earth is but a prelude to the larger life with God, and Christian understanding enables us to rejoice when Gods chosen are called to their inherritence.
